I've got a morbid curiosity and I'm good with people (common medfag personality traits), so I don't really mind, I actually really like my job. If you're not shocked by the old and sick, a hospital isn't that bad of a working environment.

>>28317140
Any adult male looking to hug kids (specially little girls) will sounds like a pedo. Similarly, any guy committing the act will look like one UNLESS it's his own kid, or maybe a relative's.
A friend's kid might work too (if the parents are okay with it)? If you are unwilling to produce the child yourself, or to date a single mom (sounds like you don't want a long term commitment for the hug? Just a hug and done kind of deal), then I guess a friend's kid is the only way.

Don't you have any acquaintances who have children or are waiting for one? If you don't, start looking for ones to be friendly with. Though it might be difficult as a single male to get friendly with a married couple, and even if you are friends, you won't necessarily get in a situation where you met their kids (this would be much easier if you had kids of your own so you could bond over it).

Best case scenario would be having someone you are close friends with, who sometimes invite you to a barbecue or something with a lot of other people including their own family (with probably other people's kids as well), it would be awkward if you are the only single male there but not unheard of (which is why being close friends is important, so people don't question why you are there).
Once you are there, do not, I repeat DO NOT be alone with a kid in any circumstance, it's fine to play with the children but not too much (it's better if you don't actually), and do not expect or initiate an act of hugging (or any other intimacy).
The ideal scenario for legally hugging a kid you are not related with would be where 1) the kid themselves initiate an act of hugging (with other people looking so you have an alibi) or 2) the situation calls for the kid to hug every other adult in the room already (like in a birthday party or something). Some kids are friendly or touchy so 1 is not out of question but 2 is more likely.

Also make sure to take to the grave and not express loudly your desire to hug kids.

>How do you overcome severe trauma?

How most people overcome severe trauma:
1. Want to not have it
2. When mindsets / behaviours / feelings / memories / habits / etc related to the trauma happen, the person tries instead to not have/do them.
3. Over time, the person adapts to have less trauma.

How you overcome severe trauma:
1. Decide you actually want to have it since it gives you excuses for all the shit you keep doing
2. Don't actually want to change or try to change because it's more convenient for you to make the same excuses
3. Feel a little bit sad but not sad enough to actually consider changing

posts.sub: I told my dad that I hate him
posts.com:
We were all under the assumption that my young 13-year-old sister went out with her friends to a party.

I got home at around 11 pm (she was supposedly picked up by her friend at around 8-9) thinking she was already out and my dad confirmed it. I thought that it was too late for someone her age to be out this late, so I started calling her. A few calls soon became several dozen. I was extremely worried, all while my dad was drinking and dancing to loud music, telling me not to worry.

It was 1 am and I was furious. I confronted my dad and criticized his poor parenting skills, his alcohol abuse, his priorities, his emotionally distant nature, etc. I even brought up how most of my immediate family and I were in the hospital room where my mother died that night and all he did was stay at home and drink. I said that I sincerely hated him, thinking something horrible happen to my little sister. It wasn't fair that I was worried sick while he was drunk and unbothered.

As it turns out, she was sleeping in her room the entire time. We respect each other's privacy, which includes not going into anybody else's room while they're not home. My older sister and I were out and about so my dad was the only one home with my little sister. The little one even told me that she informed my dad that she was going to sleep. He must've been so out of it to not remember that, hence why everyone thought she went out.

Now, my father is upset at me for overreacting and bitching at him for allowing her to go out this late. For a brief second, he thought I was fucking with him on purpose, just so I could rant about his inadequacies as a father, when I told him that she was in her room sleeping. I know this will put a strain on us, but his reliance on alcohol "to relax" negatively affects his relationship with his daughter.

I love my old man when he's not drunk, but man do I loathe him when he is. I don't know how to talk to him going forward, especially if he's not quitting anytime soon.

THis is the thing:
when we were kids, my mom used to pretend to call "the wolf" on the phone when we were being inconvenient (she hates children, she thought we were being bad, but in hindsight, we were just being children) to eat us.

But i was smart enough that even from age 4 i knew that didn't make any sense. So for me, she did something different (only a couple of times, but it was enough).

she would say she's calling the orphanage to see if there's anybody who would take me. i was such a bad kid, that she didn't know if anybody would take me off her hands. so i would sit in my room for like an hour waiting, and then she'd come in and say "they found a family willing to take you, but they'll only allow you to take one bag of toys." so i had to go through all of my things and fill up one bag with things to take and leave the rest behind. when i was done, she'd come back into the room and say that it all fell through and that they didn't want me, so, unless the orphanage calls back with another family, i'm staying here for the time being.

it was traumatizing enough that when my mom would go out for the night with friends or something, i would sleep with this photo of my mom because i thought i might never see her again. my dad found me once and teased me about it.

i feel like a total cunt whining about this to my counselor, so i want to get it off my chest here.
sorru sorry

You seem to have a distorted view of the situation. Abusers tend to put in the mind of their victims that they are whiners, weak minds that just complain too, that they have to be stronger, that, in fact, it is for their own good. Always good to be stronger, right? Makes sense. Except when it's used to supress one's rightful emotions. Years later here you are, still unsure, because someone put in your head that what you felt was no valid. Again, it's typical in cases of abuse. They'll teach you your feelings aren't valid and try to rewrite history in your mind, they will blame their own problems (real ones, you know, not like yours) to justify their behaviour, and they will condition you into ignoring yourself. How do you expect to be able to move on from something painful if you don't even feel entitled to acknowledge the pain it causes you? Abusers all do the same. Largely predictable group people. They go little by little, increasing your tolerance to abusive behaviours. Of course as a child you can't do shit about it, but as an adult you have choices, you can protect yourself. Seeing a therapist is a good idea. Say it all. He'll help you identify the patterns the abuse followed, and how it skewed your perception.
That little story about your mother you shared here is anything but harmless. It fostered in you a fear of abandonment, and feelings of unworthiness, at the very age you're supposed to be learning the contrary of that. See the therapist, man.

>>28330267
A guy being attracted to you doesn't mean that he'll have a lot to say to you all the time. Autism, general introversion, or shallow attraction (primary reason for their interest is physical) can all be factors in a guy not talking to you much.
It also depends on how you expect them to talk to you--texting is different from talking in real life. Personally, I'm very introverted and HATE texting.

Not sure why this post in particular got swarmed by angry incels, but I will say that if you feel best with a particular dynamic (whether that's getting periodic "thinking about you" texts, a visible effort to make time for each other when you can, or something else), you should try to communicate your preferences, and be willing to walk away if they don't seem to "get" you. Being earnest is fine, but begging for attention and panicking that you aren't attractive is not.
Otherwise you risk being taken for granted or, worse, getting manipulated, because at minimum, the replies you're getting here show some guys do actually think that way.

"washing" rice depends on how you cook it. if you saute it, washing actually significantly changes how the rice cooks, as it washes away a lot of the exterior dusty starch which would otherwise cook into/onto the rice.

boiling it does affect somewhat if you wash or don't wash it, however it's more subtle and often only applies if you intend to simmer/boil off the water nearly all the way, beyond what you normally boil into it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28328789>>28328752
not to mention if it's enriched rice, you're specifically told by the packaging to not wash it because if you do you're washing off the extra added minerals.

washing rice for safety is mostly antiquated now that most people get it in prepackaged plastic bags, but if you do ever get rice wholesale in a burlap sack or something you should wash it. Other than that washing rice has very slight culinary effects, but if you're just a home cook you probably won't notice or care anyway.
Trad asians will tell you off for it and call you disgusting for not washing your plastic bag rice because it's just a part of their culture and they don't think about it, they are wrong.

Always wash your rice. Do it twice; pour water in, then stir until cloudy. Lightly knead the rice with your hands for a while, then stir it again. Where were your migraines expressing themselves? Over the eyes? Back of the head? Temples?
How's your sleep? Are you getting 8+ hours a night?

Anything canned with acidic foods, especially tomatoes should not be used. With your condition being as it is I would try to rule them out altogether. In this situation your endocrine has become somewhat pathological and it's probably an entire environment's worth of factors that have brought this state about.

The endocrine system is a network of organs throughout the body all of which work to maintain a hormonal homeostasis. If even one of these organs is in stress it stresses the rest of them out as well and if the environmental issues are not resolved a pathological homeostasis takes form which creates a normal state of unhealth. The problem, once this happens, is that to break an existing homeostasis requires a sharp shock to it. So you may have to make some drastic changes in order to turn things around.

Here are a few of them, there are more but these are the most important:

Vitamin D3 deficiency is a worldwide epidemic. Vitamin D is not really a vitamin, it's a prohormone and it plays myriad of roles throughout the entirety of our organism. You may want to get a blood test which tests for both the active and inactive form of vitamin D to see where your levels really are. Regardless, with most people being deficient I strongly suggest supplementing with 5000-10,000IU a day especially during the winter and the times where you're not getting sunlight. Vitamin D3 should be taken with K2 as vitamin K2 ensures that the vitamin-d associated calcium ends up where it's needed and not in the areas where it can induce trouble. As for a supplement, I recommend the Dr. Berg brand as it's the cheapest combo with U.S. made ingredients.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28320794
The liver is a secondary organ in the endocrine system but its role should not be written off. When you take NSAIDs regularly, which is particularly common for women with painful menstrual cycles, you begin to deteriorate your liver's capacity. Since you're having so many recurring migraines I can only imagine how often you rely on these to get through the day. To stop taking them is probably not an option, nor would I want you to suffer. But what you should do is chase every NSAID with at least 600mg of N-Acetyl-Cysteine, preferably Pure Encapsulations brand as they're a U.S. manufacturer that doesn't use Chinese ingredients. NAC helps replete the master antioxidant glutathione within your liver which NSAIDs rapidly deplete. Chronic use of NSAIDs will keep your liver in a perpetual state of unhealth by suppressing glutathione levels which can, over time, exacerbate and further allow this pathological homeostasis of your endocrine system to persist.

From what I'm observing based off what you have provided you are expressing multiple symptoms of estrogen dominance. This can be overcome but to break the current homeostasis requires a shock. The strongest shock you can provide, in my opinion, is fasting. I think a 3 a day water fast every month for 4-6 months might be exactly what you need to start recovering. If you are the type of person that eats three meals a day you may want to work yourself to one meal a day before going for a three day fast. To go from three meals a day to no meals a day is really difficult for people doing their first multi-day fast. You can do it, it's just more stress on the body than it would be if you were already eating one meal a day.

posts.com:
>>28320800

Second, you're going to want to get an intracellular magnesium and potassium test as these are the electrolytes that are most often related to estrogen dominance and glandular function. You need to specifically ask for an intracellular test for these electrolytes as they are intracellular electrolytes (98-99% are within your cells). If you rely upon a blood serum test you're not going to be able to adequately diagnose a deficiency until its in its latest stages. For some, magnesium can make migraines worse so use caution with them. I would start with magnesium glycinate and then work from there if that form of Mg induces migraines. Try to find a form of magnesium that does not stimulate migraines if you can, don't give up if the first brand/type you try induces them. For potassium I recommend buying Dr. Berg's electrolyte powder as it has 1000mg of potassium (4,700mg is the recommended daily intake) per scoop. It's the most affordable way to supplement with potassium that I have found. Most potassium in the diet comes from vegetables so you may want to try to figure out how much you need to supplement with to ensure you're meeting your dietary requirement.

Third thing you're going to want to do is clear the body out of heavy metals which you have been accumulating throughout your life. The safest way to do this is by way of Modified Citrus Pectin. 5mg/3x/day for 1 month (PectaSol / Econeugenics brand) should clear the majority of what can be cleared out minus what has been sequestered in bone of course. As a side note, I would also ditch any teflon cookware that you have and replace them with cast iron, ceramic, stainless steel or carbon steel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28320807
Next you will need to deal with your drinking water issue. Bottled water inevitably leaches chemicals from the plastics even if it's a BPA-free plastic. I recommend dropping money on a distilled water system and adding your own trace minerals to it or using electrolyte powders to get the needed electrolytes. The brand of distiller I recommend is the My Pure Water brand:

https://mypurewater.com/shop/mini-classic-ct-distiller/

I own this one myself and it's a great machine; it's easy to maintain and only requires a once a month cleaning to keep going. If you're making soups, broths or use water for boiling to make rice/pasta then I would also invest in an undersink filter to filter out your municipal water, especially fluoride which is notorious for wreaking havoc to the endocrine system (I'll get to fluoride more in a second). The system I use is this one:

https://www.amazon.com/Frizzlife-SK99-NEW-Certified-Chlorine-Chloramine/dp/B08NDYVZV5/

As for fluoride, I would immediately stop using fluoride toothpastes. I would also be mindful of any canned foods packed in water (often packed in municipal fluoridated water) and if you can get a flouride-rated shower filter that would be helpful as well. The problem with fluoride is that it accumulates as it's readily retained at a rate of 35% - 50% of that which is ingested (younger people retaining more than adults). And when fluoride gets retained it gets sequestered in bone. The presence of iodine triggers its release and removal and there has been some brewing hypotheses regarding using iodine as a way of treating long-term fluoride toxicity.

>>28322413
>Is it worth moving out
It's circumstantial so I'll run through a couple of scenarios, assuming you live somewhere that's kind of expensive eg a capital city:
>Moving out with friends
Yes, rent is often manageable if you're living with a couple of mates (2-3 others is best) and the freedom you experience is intoxicating. When people say high-school is the best time of your life, include the couple of years after high school when you're just having fun with your friends and learning life. Even if you're on struggle street for a little, as long as your friends are hard-up as well it really isn't an issue because you all manage together. Bonus points if you have a goal during this time like finishing university.
>moving out with strangers
60/40, if you get a good house it can be almost as good as above, if you get shitty housemates you'll be more miserable than when you're at home. Bonus points if you're living near other friends while doing this.
>moving out on your own
Rarely worth it if you can still do everything you want to do while at your parents. Rent is way too much and you're going to struggle until you're earning properly. If you can't do what you want while living with your parents (either too far away or too strict parents) then this can still be okay but it's not a care-free lifestyle since you've got such high overheads with rent and bills. My advice is sus-out with friends a potential living arrangement and work towards that in the mean time.

Moving out at 19 with some friends from the country to the city for university kicked off some of the most fun years of my life, even at 29 I look back fondly at 19-24

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28329584
Look for "scripts" on reddit. My wife is a bit 'spectrumy' sometimes and she has found a lot of success just being handed the answer key for various situations. I will give you some general hints though.

1. Some people like to talk about themselves, so ask questions about them.
2. People especially like to talk about the things they like, so ask about hobbies and interests.
3. Asking follow up questions shows interest, especially if you can show some kind of insight into the subject at hand.
4. Make eye contact, but not the entire conversation, try to aim for about half the time. If it is difficult for you look at their eyebrows, it looks about the same from their perspective and it is a lot easier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28323697

Leadership is the ability to induce subordinates to WANT to do the right thing. A manager can order someone to run up a hill on a bright, sunny day to watch clouds.
A leader can make someone WANT TO run up a hill while being shot at with machine guns knowing the goal is to kill enough of the enemy to get the job done before they person doing the running dies.

I am quite sure you know what the other cooks *should* be doing. And I am sure you are telling them what to do.
But you aren't leading them.
Simple early steps

1) listen more than you talk. These people are more experienced at what thy do than you are. Give them a legit chance to teach you, actually learn, and find out what they think can be done better
2) That said make sure decisions are yours.
3) Never treat everyone in your team the same. Be *fair* but a hard worker that is on time and helps others can be safely trusted and just check he's ok from time to time; a slacker that needs training should be watched and helped to improve
4) Do your job and let them do theirs. 'Micromanaging' usually boils down to the manager trying to do the job and treating an employee like a tool used by the manager. This is infuriating.
5) You had better be harder working, more loyal, and more competent if you are in a high stress competitive environment. You should exhibit the same punctuality, professionalism, commitment to excellence, and so on you expect from your subordinates and they should know this without being told.
6) No one, and I mean NO ONE, "owes you" respect as a manager. Bad managers can ruin entire companies. They can shatter well-trained, highly-skilled teams. If you are put in a leadership position over a team and that team's performance drops that is ALLL YOU. If they think badly of your for hurting their performance they are correct.

Take the chip off your shoulder, stop pretending this is about your dick/lack of a dick, and either lead or leave

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28329837
I like to keep it light during the day and eat a big meal at night. Generally for breakfast I have orange juice, cream of tartar, and some salt then a glass of kefir and maybe some coffee if I need it. Then I don't just eat once for lunch, when I am feeling a bit hungry I'll have some cheese, crackers and salami then an hour or so later I'll have some yogurt then a bit after that I might have some fresh fruit and a granola/protein bar. The less carbs I have throughout the day the more energy I have and the less lethargic I feel. And for dinner I am always making something different that sound good but generally some variation of chicken, rice and vegetables.

What is most important is to eat nutrient dense foods that you enjoy. There is no reason to meal plan plain chicken, shitty calrose rice and frozen broccoli. Think about some of the recipes you like, prepare anything you can ahead of time to make your cooking time shorter, get a vacuum sealer, marinade your meat, get a pressure cooker.

Also overnight oats is one of my favorite low effort breakfasts and I just learned there is a fermented version which is even better for you. You should check it out.

>>28325365
I think it depends what you want out of the experience. An LSD trip is a little over twice as long as a mushroom trip. LSD feels a little more energetic to me while mushrooms feel a little more sedative and usually bring on a little nausea. A half gram of mushrooms or a half hit of acid are probably going to be pretty manageable doses for someone, even a first timer, doing this alone.
What you definitely need to keep in mind is to not do these kinds of drugs often. They can seriously change you, and if you keep doing these drugs often without having spent enough time integrating those changes then you can easily fry your brain. People online like to recommend you wait at least two weeks to trip again purely for the sake of tolerance, but I honestly think you should wait at least a month or more between trips.
That being said, I also think you can trip for purely recreational reasons and will likely have some fun with these experiences alongside your intended reason for taking them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dating apps are based off of algorithms, so women with those tastes are going to be promoted more -- there are plenty who don't look good in photos.
Women are good at posing because they practice it a lot (same with men). Generally, it's just learned through trial and error from posting social media pics and talking to their friends about it.
For starting, I would focus on good lighting (like no harsh shadows that make you look like a serial killer) and looking natural -- which would be face angles and poses that reflect what you look like irl (a single lens on a camera struggles to show how two constantly adjusting eyes see you, and this is why people usually look different in photos), you also don't have to be a chad to get matches.
It would also be good to have friends to help you, especially if they have good taste in photos (or some photography knowledge), so you don't end up with someone like my mom taking pictures who thinks every photo of you looks good.
It could also take some time to create a profile depending on how many pictures you currently have, probably in the timeline of a few weeks -- assuming you start from 0.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28327350
Yah same here, pretty much all my pastimes were on the computer. While they are really fun I have found in the long run they are some of the most unfulfilling I could have possible done.
>How demanding is taking care of the aquarium?
Hard question to answer because there's a huge range of animals and types of aquariums, ultimately I would say not very demanding if you take things slow and limit how many animals you buy. Stuff will go wrong so you basically spend some time reading up or watching youtube videos and then apply that knowledge on the weekends. During the week you observe. Repeat till you have your own little balanced ecosystem. I keep very little fish so the water doesn't get filled with waste and I don't have to clean very often. Maybe 30-45 minutes every two weeks to change water and clean the glass. You can also just get fancy shrimp like pic, a few in a tank will pretty much just feed themselves forever and produce very little waste. There's also more pet type aquatic animals you can get like a big ole crayfish or cichlids. You could have a tank with just that one and a few fish you take care of. Check out the aquarium general on /an/ or ask away here I can help as much as I can to get started.

>What about community college, do you work and study at the same time?
Yah I work full time, I will only take one class at a time to not overload myself and limit myself to entry level courses. I also don't want to have to write page long essays and spend hours studying. I usually do take night classes or early morning classes. The exams aren't bad at all, for me they all take place the same day as class so I would have been anyways. Above all though I remind myself I'm just here to satisfy my desire to learn and not jump through the academic hoops for a degree. I also took language classes at this community college, it was a good experience. Of course academic settings have their problems, I would go in with a kinda detached mindset.

posts.sub: How do I put an end to my boring life?
posts.com:
Every day i'm usually just tired from college, and especially since i'm off work until some time next month due to weather, I end up usually just terminally online and it's been getting to me more often as the time passes by. I have stuff that I wanna do, but I end up just succumbing to the lack of motivation and energy. I have some hobbies that I want to expand on, and also I want to see if there's anything else that I enjoy. Especially since my PC has ended up pissing me off more than ever, I wanna make the most out of my life, and to a lesser extent I wanna maybe be a bit more interesting, if that doesn't sound more sad than it did in my head?

So my question, how exactly is the best way to find more hobbies to enjoy, and keep myself motivated with others?

To list a couple examples of the hobbies with little motivation:

Exercise/weight loss: This year I wanted to make my year to finally lean down, but I never ended up getting to it, for the reasons listed above but also i've held things off due to a messy area. Cleaning this room again tomorrow, and hopefully after that i'll finally get a session in at least once a week.

Music/drawing/other art: These are a bit different but the reason for why is pretty much the same. Every composition I come up with or every sketch I draw looks like trash, I have zero confidence in it, and then I end up trashing it.

Anime/game/media consumption: This one I chalk up to procrastination and nothing really exciting me anymore, but moreso procrastination.

For a couple i've wanted to get into:

Reading: I just don't know where to start, how to find anything else I wanna read. I don't wanna be stuck with a couple manga I picked up, I wanna read traditional literature as well.

Yeah that was the only one on the top of my head.

Also, if anyone has any recommendations for others, i'm happy to hear what you have to offer, if you need to ask anything to figure it out, ask away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28327120
First of all, your mindset is wrong.

Its not about "finding motivation". Its about being disciplined.

Nobody who is exceptional at something and does it everyday is "motivated" like it's a drug or a constant high. They just do it. Its discipline. You do it when you're tired, when you dont feel like it, even when you had the worst day ever. You have to train your brain to be disciplined, not chasing "motivation" bullshit like a drug. This is the same thing as happiness. If you chase happiness and instant gratification you will never be happy.

Good things take time, anon. Good luck. Take responsility over your life and embrace a life of discipline.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28327120
Like >>28327206 mentioned, it all comes down to discipline, not necessarily motivation.

I was in your spot some time ago. There was so much stuff I wanted to do but it took effort and wasting time being online was so much more "relaxing". It screws you over in the long run though. Honestly the best way to do your hobbies is literally to just do them. Don't give any thought to how much better it would be if "I just skipped today/ I'll do it tomorrow."

With regards to exercising, I've found that once you incorporate it into your weekly routine it's harder not to do it. I go to my uni gym between classes. But what do you do if you don't have breaks? Make time: wake up earlier and go to bed late. I know it's a pain in the behind and it will feel like hell at first, but that only lasts for the first week or so. After that you'll start enjoying going more and more. Plus if you make friends there it will be even better. I don't know your eating habits, but try to eat less pre-made meals and cook more often. It helps.

For reading, read some popular books until you figure out the genre/topics you like. You don't even have to read for hours at a time, just say 15 minutes before bed. A good way to find what book to read is just google "books about x". I also use goodreads to find books similar to the ones I enjoy.

For drawing and music I haven't had any personal experience with them but my advice is the same: to just do it.

I know it seems like doing all of this is a huge hurdle to cross right now but ask yourself: do you wish you'd started all these hobbies 6 months ago? If you did, imagine all the progress you would have made by now.

But it's not like you're out of time. Start now and you will thank yourself 6 months from now. It may seem like a lot but the time will honestly fly by. Good luck anon. You've got this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28323950
Just find a physical activity you enjoy. Try the gym of course, maybe you'll enjoy it. But if you don't enjoy it, you're going to give up eventually. Even light exercise is legit, if you burn 100 calories on a short daily walk around the neighbourhood that's nearly 3500 calories in a month, which roughly corresponds to a pound of body fat burnt. If you find something you enjoy you won't need to motivate yourself, it'll just be part of your life. Activity can be more fun if you involve others, maybe you can walk a dog or join a team sport. What kind of things would you be interested in trying?

Also bear in mind most of your calorie defecit will be from reducing calories consumed, rather than burning them off with exercise. That's not to say exercise isn't important of course.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28328849
cont.
People tend to pick up on the fact that you don't see yourself in a high regard, or in other words, it's intuitively apparent to people around you that you are self conscious and/or have low confidence and will treat you according to that. The first step is changing your perception about yourself. I know it's not easy, it's never easy, but you need to come to peace with your past, with yourself, and with your identity first. Identify your worries and think about the possible consequences of them in your life. Then identify the real consequences of your worries. Some people have silly worries, like about their appearance or about other people. These arise from your insecurities and may seem very believable because your subconscious makes them very believable. It's okay to have them, but you need to fix these things. Write down possible solutions to your worries. Identify the best solution to your worry. Then act on it. Try to develop coping mechanism that arise from your mind, in that way, they are more believable and you will be inclined to apply them to your life.

>>28326345
This reads like bait, but I’ll answer seriously in case it can actually help:
There’s nothing wrong with your standards. Waiting until marriage is a good thing, and it’s doable for both men and women without cheap loopholes like porn. Porn today is unfortunately very widespread, but that doesn’t mean you just need to accept what you feel is wrong. If it’s important enough to you to be a dealbreaker, you shouldn’t feel bad about sticking to your standards.

This being said, you should consider the kinds of guys you’re going for. Those who independently want to wait until marriage are showing you that they share a lot of your values, rather than just going along with them like your bf did (since he initially pressured you, showing he expects sex outside of marriage). Guys who have a past of sex outside of marriage, or who pressure you for it, are less likely to be either willing or able to not only wait but also quit porn, because they’re already starting from a belief that something as intimate as sex shouldn’t just be with their spouse.
Like another guy ITT, I have to admit to using, even being addicted to, porn, although not while in a relationship. Still, I admit it’s a flaw, and I came to that conclusion because I want to wait until marriage. It’s not the same thing as sex, but it’s a devaluation of intimacy, and it’s very easy to see why a woman wouldn’t be happy with it. Point being, guys who already value waiting/monogamy should be more motivated to not watch (or at least quit watching) porn in a relationship.
